episode.title: Johnson v. Railway Express Agency, Inc.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in 73-1543, Johnson against Railway Express Agency.
Mrs. Greenberg you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
This case comes here on a writ of certiorari to the United State's Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

The writ was directed to the question of whether the timely filing of a charge of employment discrimination with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission tolls the running of the statute of limitations applicable to an action based on the same facts brought under Section 1981.
Petitioner Willy Johnson Junior, a Black man was hired by REA Express in 1964.
In 1967, he filed with the EEOC a charge of racial discrimination against REA and two locals of the brotherhood of railway clerks.
He charged REA with discriminatory job assignments and the locals with being racially segregated.
Three weeks later, REA fired petitioner.
Petitioner then amended his EEOC charge to include discriminatory discharge.
Respondents were given notice of the charges in September 1967.
An EEOC charge -- investigation substantiated petitioner's charge.
And in March 1970, the EEOC issued a determination finding reasonable cause to believe that respondents had violated the Title VII.
After efforts at conciliation failed on January 4th 1971, petitioner received from the EEOC his notice of right to sue on January 15, 1971.
When he was unable to obtain private counsel, the District Court-appointed counsel to represent him and permitted him to file his right to sue a letter as a complaint on a pauperis oath.
On March 18, 1971, the court-appointed attorney filed a supplemental complaint alleging violation of both Title VII and Section 1981.
Respondents filed motions to dismiss or for summary judgment with supporting affidavits and memoranda of law.
Petitioner's court-appointed attorney filed no papers in opposition.

The court dismissed all claims under Section 1981 as barred by the Tennessee one year statute of limitations on actions for compensatory or punitive damages brought under Federal Civil Right statutes.

On a record which contained undisputed evidence of the maintenance of segregated locals and higher membership dues for Blacks, the court granted summary judgment to the “unions on the grounds that plaintiffs had, “No grounds for relief under Title VII” and granted partial summary judgment to REA on the issue of the lack of supervisory training.

The issues that remained in the case were claims under Title VII against REA for discriminatory job assignment referral to segregated locals, discriminatory application of seniority rules -- discriminatory discharge and discriminatory disciplinary action.
The case was set for trial and REA took discovery and filed a pretrial memorandum as required by the local rules of court.
Petitioner's court-appointed attorney did nothing. REA then offered petitioner a settlement of $150.00.
And when petitioner refused this offer, his court-appointed counsel filed a motion to withdraw.

The court clerk advised the petitioner by letter, that the motion of which petitioner had received no notice had been granted and that if petitioner did not obtain another lawyer within 30 days, his case would be dismissed.
Petitioner went to the local legal aid society, to the bar association referral service and to two private attorneys to whom he was referred by the EEOC, all to no avail.
Finally, he went to a Memphis law firm and explained his plight to William Caldwell.

I should explain at this point that when petitioner first received his right to sue a letter, he went to the same firm and they were unable to take his case because of the great number of Title VII cases to which the court had appointed them.
Caldwell wrote to the Chief Judge of the District Court stating that he was attempting to obtain support for the suit and requesting an additional 30 days to obtain counsel.
But just the day before, on February 16, 1972, an order had been entered dismissing petitioner's case without prejudice.

On May 5th, Caldwell again wrote the District -- the Chief Judge indicating that the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund had agreed to pay the cost of litigation entering an appearance and requesting that the order of dismissal be vacated.
The Chief Judge wrote back suggesting that it would be appropriate for Caldwell to file a new action.
On May 31, Caldwell filed a new complaint under both Title VII and Section 1981 reiterating petitioner's original allegations.
The District Court dismissed the complaint on several grounds.

First, with respect to petitioner's Title VII claims, he held that the interlocutory order of June 14, 1971 in the first action granting summary judgment to respondent locals and partial summary judgment to REA was a final judgment constituting res judicata.

Second, that petitioner's claims under Section 1981 were barred by Tennessee's one year statute of limitations and also barred because of petitioner's failure exhaust remedies under the Railway Labor Act.
Third, he held that petitioner's Title VII action against REA was barred by his failure to re-file within 30 days after the dismissal without prejudice.
The Court of Appeals affirmed disposing of the case on timeliness grounds.

It held that the Title VII action was barred because the second action was filed more than 30 days after the dismissal of the first action and held that the statute of limitations on petitioner's Section 1981 action was not told by the filing of his EEOC charge.
Rehearing was denied.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you going to tell us a little bit about what administrative remedies were available if any under the Railway Act?
Or do you --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: No, Your Honor, that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I take the position that isn't the real, genuine meaning for remedy?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: We would take the position that there are independent remedies under Section 1981 and Title VII.

We -- in our petition for certiorari asked the court to review the holding that the plaintiffs -- petitioners should have exhausted his remedies under the Railway Labor Act and the court did not agree to review that question.

Petitioner and the United States as amicus curiae urged the court to adopt the rule of the Fifth and DC circuits namely, that the filing of an EEOC charge operates to toll the running of the statute of limitations on an action based on the same facts brought under Section 1981.
If such a rule is applied to the case at bar, petitioner's Section 1981 action was timely filed under Tennessee's one year statute of limitations.
He filed his charge with the EEOC on May 31, 1967 while still employed by REA.
The discriminatory acts alleged there in were continuing in nature so that none of the one year period had run prior to said filing.
He received his notice of right to sue on January 15, 1971.
The supplemental complaint in the first action and that was the first pleading to state a cause of action under Section 1981 was filed 62 days later on March 18, 1971.
So, to that point only 62 days had run if the tolling rules were adopted.
The statute stopped running when the action was filed and did not start running again until February 16, 1972 when the action was dismissed without prejudice.
The second action was filed 105 days after the dismissal of the first action on May 31, 1972.
Thus, a total of 167 days of the Tennessee one year statute had run.

The purposes underlying the statute of limitations, notice to the defendants and the barring of stale claims by plaintiff who has slept on his rights, were served by the filing of petitioner's EEOC charge.

In Burnett versus New York Central, this Court suggested that the basic inquiry is whether congregational purpose would be effectuated by tolling the statute of limitations in the circumstances of this case.

As this Court recognize in Alexander v. Gardner-Denver, it is clear from the legislative history of Title VII that Congress intended that individual be able to pursue his rights to be free from racial discrimination and employment under both Title VII and Section 1981.
It is equally clear that Congress prefer the process of fact finding and conciliation provided in Title VII and hope that litigation would be resorted to only if this process was not effective.
Both policies can be accommodated by adopting the tolling rule urged by petitioner.
Bringing suit under Section 1981 is of course simpler than bringing suit under Title VII as there are no administrative remedies that must be exhausted.

Indeed, one of the grounds urged by the sponsors of the Equal Employment Opportunity Act of 1972 for rejecting an amendment that would have made Title VII the exclusive remedy was that procedural requirements of Title VII may sometimes prevent and aggrieve individual from obtaining redress.
And in such event, he should be able to fall back on Section 1981.
On the other hand, from the point of view of the individual with limited resources unable to obtain counsel.
Title VII is the better remedy.
The EEOC can investigate and conciliate claims and can even bring suit on behalf of complainant.
As long as a person has reason to hope that he can get the relief he seeks by resort to the EEOC he should not have to go to the expense of filing suit.

As Judge Tuttle, writing for the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting en banc in Kessler versus EEOC said, “Competent lawyers are not eager to enter the fray in behalf of a person who is seeking redress until Title VII.”
This is true even though provision is made for payment of attorney's fees in the event of success.
Therefore, he held the resources of the EEOC such as their investigatory files should be made available to the private litigant to make it less difficult for him to bring this case to court.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mrs. Greenberg, are you in any way restricting your application of your theory that is -- should the tolling effect for instance be limited to the charges raised in the EEOC complaint or should it be wide open?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: I think the tolling effect should be limited to the same extent that they would be limited in a Title VII case.
That is under the standard of Sanchez versus Standard Brands to the facts that would be likely to grow out of an investigation of the EEOC charge.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Would it have been possible for Mr. Johnson to have filed his 1981 action before the period of limitation expired and then just kind of sit on it, he'd have to have the approval of court I suppose.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes, that would have been possible but we've seen no reason for bargaining the court calendars with cases which are going to be sat on.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if it takes as it does with some of the agencies Mrs. Greenberg, I won't mention any particular agency but some of them take four or five years or more.
Does that give you any problems?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: This is a problem.

It is a problem that has been raised in -- respondent's principal argument is that almost four years past between the filing of the EEOC charge and the recede of petitioner's notice of right to sue and that the point that respondents make is the allowing petitioner to file an action after such a long period to have worked in injustice on the respondents.
But Congress must have intended that aggrieved employees could take advantage of all of the investigative and conciliatory processes of the EEOC otherwise, they could have required --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll resume there right after lunch.
Mrs. Ginsberg you have about 15 -- 16 minutes left.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.
Before recess I was responding to a question of the Chief Justice.

As the problem of delay, Congress must have intended that aggrieved employees could take advantage of all the investigative and conciliatory processes of the EEOC even though that might mean not filing a civil action under Title VII for several years.
The legislative history is replete with material about the backlog in the EEOC.
Congress could have required the EEOC to issue right to sue letters within a specified time after the filing of a charge.
If -- putting all kinds of short limitations on the times we're doing certain things that did not put in a limitation on how long a matter could be before the EEOC.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, are you arguing that the commencement of the first action itself told the statute?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.
I think that the commencement of an act --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That question -- is that question here?
That's the problem that's been giving me some trouble.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: That question is not here.
We would argue that just as a matter of common sense that a statue of limitations on the commencement of an action would have to stop running with the commencement of the action.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If you are arguing to sustain the judgment of the court you could use any argument you wanted probably or almost any argument.
I'm having a little trouble with that one if --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Oh, we could further argue that even if the commencement of the first action did not toll but running of the statute on the time for filing that action, that the second action was brought within a year after dismissal of the first action as allowed by the Tennessee saving statute which provides for bringing -- in the case of any action dismissed without a determination on the merits.
It could be filed within a year.

Affirmance of the decision below would not only do violence to congressional policy with respect to preserving a petitioner's right of action under 1981 and its policy of the same time of encouraging resort to the conciliatory processes of the EEOC but would also -- could also have adverse effects on the federal judicial system.
The aggrieved employee would have to file his EEOC charge, file suit under 1981 if he could obtain counsel.
And very likely see his action come to judgment on his 1981 action before the EEOC have had the chance to investigate his charge.
If he did not file suit, he would run the risk of foregoing his rights under Section 1981 and running a file of the procedural requirements of Title VII as the petitioner.
One can only speculate about the number of such precautionary suits that might be filed.
However, the EEOC informs us that in fiscal 1974, it received over 50,000 new charges.
Of the charges investigated and which decisions were issued, 44% were found to be without probable cause.

As this Court observed in Alexander versus Gardner-Denver with respect to the conciliatory or therapeutic processes of arbitration, the processes of the EEOC may satisfy an employee's perceived need to resort to the judicial forum.

This Court's recent holding in American Pipe versus Utah, that the avoidance of precautionary litigation is a sound reason for tolling a statute of limitations is equally applicable to the instant case.
Respondents contend in their briefs that the principles of Burnett and American Pipe do not apply to this case because they involved the tolling of federal, not state statutes of limitations.

This contention was squarely rejected in Holmberg versus Armbrecht where Mr. Justice Frankfurter stated, it would be too incongruous to confine a federal right within the bare terms of a state's statute of limitations unrelieved by the settled federal equitable doctrine as to fraud.
When even a federal statute in the same terms would be given the mitigating construction required by that doctrine.
I would like to reserve my remaining time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Wisehart.

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
My opponent is in error in stating that the commission had concluded that conciliation had failed in this case.
In actual fact as page 75A of the record shows, the right to sue a letter was issued in response to a request from the petitioner in this case.
The case involved 10 employees.

So far as I am informed the commission has never concluded conciliation efforts and it did not advise the petitioner that its efforts had failed which brings into play Section 29, CFR Section 160125 (b) of the commission's regulations.
That provision states that when a right to sue letter has been issued at the request of a complainant then the commissions proceedings shall suspend.
That is the word of the regulation.

Now, the consequence of that I submit is that the commission's proceedings are still in a state off suspense and if this Court is to hold the commission proceedings, toll the running of a statute of limitations under the 1866 Act that state of suspense could go on for an indefinite period.
Something that was entirely not contemplated by Congress when it passed the 1964 Act and specified that judicial action in these cases must begin properly.

I simply do not see how it can be asserted, that given the effect to a tolling principle in this case would be consistent with the will of Congress when the most recent pronouncement of Congress on the subject has underscored the need for fast resolution of these disputes.
The question regarding the Railway Labor Act remedies is that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I suppose that the acceptable matter is -- you could say that the statute would have to be satisfied within the time of the Title VII suit?

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: Well, that is one alternative that may be open to this Court.
But it is not open on the facts of this case because under the law of the case as it stands, the time for Title VII suit here has expired.
And all of the cases relied upon by petitioner --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: That is correct.
All of the cases that are relied upon by petitioner are distinguishable on that basis.
There has been no case holding that the time pursuing under the 1866 --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you saying that even if -- even if your opponents are riding on the initial tolling -- they are really are cutout by the fact of Title VII suit, it can't be filed?

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: That is correct Your Honor and I believe this Court has two courses open to it.
It can either affirm the decision below on that narrow issue and say, “We're simply not going to hold the tolling applies when it would extend beyond the period provided by Congress in the 1964 Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you say our limitation, (Inaudible) do you think was -- you almost decided it?

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: Yes, I do Your Honor.
But the court could decide it on that narrow ground.

They were not going to hold here, that it can extend beyond the period allowed in the 1964 Act and reserve for another day the question posed by Guerra against Manchester Terminal in the Fifth Circuit which I understand they are going to petition for certiorari on.
They can either decide -- the court can either decide on the narrow ground or it can decide on the broader ground which we have brief in this case.
And that is that under the 1866 Act which does have in it Section 1988, Congress has said specifically that you must refer to state law.
Now, there's no dispute in this case that for the purpose of referring the state law, you do refer to the state statute of limitations.
The only question in this case is if under Section 1988 you must refer to state law for limitations periods, whether you must also refer to state law for the purpose of tolling.
And we submit Your Honor that it does not make sense to refer to state law for one limited purpose when tolling and statute of limitations are all part impartial of the same statutory framework.

So that the cases that do not deal with the effect of Section 1988 sidestep the issue and the case that it does deal with that case, the best recent case I submit is the case in the Third Circuit, Ammlung against City of Chester which was decided under Section 1983 and other Section of the 1866 Act.And in the Ammlung case, the Third Circuit focused specifically on the effect of 1988 and it said, “If you're going to refer to the state law for the purpose of the statute of limitations, you must also refer to the state law for the purpose of the tolling provision.”
That is the holding in Ammlung.
They -- Ammlung holding also speaks of the disarray that is found in the Fifth Circuit cases on this subject.
The Fifth Circuit cases go both ways.
You can cite two cases in the Fifth Circuit in our favor and you could cite two cases from the Fifth Circuit in the favor of petitioner and those are not dispositive.
As far as the District of Columbia Circuit case is concerned, that is dictum because the court found that the alleged discrimination in that case was a -- of a continuing nature.
Now, I would like to speak about a case that the petitioner relies on principally.
And that's the Moviecolor case in the Second Circuit.
The Moviecolor case was an antitrust case and in extensive dictum not necessary for the disposition of a case.
Judge Friendly has analyzed what is this doctrine of federal tolling?

The decision of Judge Friendly makes it clear that going all the way back to the case of Bailey against Glover decided by this Court in 1874 in 21 Wallace, the concept of federal tolling applies: one, where there is a federal statute of limitation, and remember we are talking here about an admitted application of a state statute not a federal statute of limitation or alternatively where there is fraud or concealment involved.

Indeed, that portion of the Moviecolor case that is quoted on page three of the reply brief for petitioner makes it quite clear that Judge Friendly's decision there is premised upon the concept of concealment.
And concealment is not an issue in this case.
More importantly then what the quotation set forth on page three shows we submit is the language that's contained in what was deleted from that quotation.
On page three of the reply brief, it appears that the quotation provided by the petitioner is the beginning of a paragraph.
But in fact the sentence that begins that paragraph reads as follows.
In the last analysis, decision of that issue namely tolling requires an attempt to divine a purpose of Congress on a subject where no purpose has been manifested.
If indeed, it was had.
Now, we submit that that language is dispositive of this case because Congress has manifested a purpose.
It has enacted Section 1988 of the 1866 Act in which for purposes of these cases reference is made to state law.
That's entirely apart from the concept of borrowing from state statutes as a matter of comity this is a congressional directive.
When Congress passed the 1964 Act, it did not focus upon this question.

As this Court's decision in Jones against Mayer Company shows, that Congress did not seem to be aware of the 1866 Act when it enacted the 1964 Act in this Court's opinion and the Jones case does say that therefore it cannot be expected that the 1964 Act had any effect upon preexisting rights.
That's the holding of this Court.
Subsequently, Congress did focus on the existence of the 1866 Act partly as a result of this Court's decision against Jones against Mayer in 1966.
And in the legislative history of the amendments to the 1972 Act, it's made clear that Congress did not intend to affect existing rights under prior legislation.
That is what the legislative history shows.
So that we have a situation in which as Moviecolor points out, the purpose is to inquire into what Congress intended.
And here you have three evidences of congressional intent.
First, you have what they said in 1988 of the 1866 Act which is you refer as state law.
Secondly, we have the 1964 Act in the subsequent decision of this Court in Jones in which it is held that Congress did not intend to effect rights under preexisting legislation.
The third evidence of congressional intent is what Congress itself provided in the Act of 1964.
And that is that lawsuits must be brought at an earlier time then is possible or is contended for by the petitioners in this case.
The effect of the tolling which they seek in this case would be to extend the time for lawsuits beyond that which Congress itself provided in its most recent enactment on this question.

And in view of those three indications of congressional intent and in view of the fact that the analysis of Judge Friendly in Moviecolor shows that application of tolling to the facts of this case which do not involve fraud or concealment would be pushing the doctrine farther that it has ever been pushed before.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you know of anything that would have prevented the Congress from providing that -- and actions could be brought within six months to one-year or some fixed period after some described cutoff point in the EEOC proceeding?

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: That is in effect of what they did as far as the EEOC cases are concerned under Title VII.
They must sue now within a specified time after the EEOC proceeding ends under Title VII.
But Congress was silent as to the effect on the 1866 Act.

You would ask in an earlier question Mr. Chief Justice about whether or not the first case here had the effect of tolling the action under the earlier act and my opponent is correct that the question has never really been focused on here.

However, the law of this case we submit is that the first action could not have had the effect of tolling because the court did instruct that further litigation be commenced within a specified time and as the Court of Appeals mentioned --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you don't even get to that question --

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: No you don't.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) if you're incorrect, the first suit was affirmative--

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: That's correct.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If -- but if you're wrong, if you're wrong on that and the first suit was filed at the time, wouldn't you say that the -- while that suit was pending, the statute was tolled?

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: Except for the fact that it became the law of the case, that further proceedings --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let's assume that the first case was still pending and had never been decided yet, is that your (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: Your Honor, I respectfully submit that the court's --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, no, expire and the suit become barred on it pending?

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: That may be Your Honor except I wish to draw the court's attention to the fact that the court in the first suit did specify a period of time in which further action should be brought and there was no appeal from that as the Court of Appeals pointed out at 107(a) of the record and that that was a final decision so that that would seem to be res judicata on the issue.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's another point.

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And while it was pending, that statute was tolled.

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: I think that one could infer that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It (Voice Overlap) in the first suit.

turn.speaker: arthur_m_wisehart
turn.label: Mr. Arthur M. Wisehart
turn.text: Yes.
Now, there was a question also on the Railway Labor Act procedures.

The decision below was that prior resort was required under the Railway Labor Act procedures and that would be dispositive of this case even if the court should rule in petitioner's favor because there was a question raised but certiorari was not granted.

Furthermore, the record indicates that this is precisely the kind of case in which the common law of the shop should be applied and could have been applied with respect to the petitioner because it involved the application of a system, of the merits, a number of particular charges and he could have been represented in that system without cause to himself unless he pursued that system of industrial justice that is provided in that way.
I don't know how he could establish that he had been damaged.
The reference was made to the fact that his prior counsel had recommended settlement which the petitioner did not agree with.

I think that if one raised the deposition of petitioner in this case, one can see why his prior counsel recommended settlement, because petitioner admitted in his deposition that because of the massive layoffs in REA employees with 25 years seniority were those who could retain jobs and he only had seven years seniority in 1971.
He admitted that he would have been laid off under normal application of the company's reduction enforce system two years before his deposition was taken.
So, one can well understand why his first counsel recommended settlement.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Highsaw.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
The two union local largest of the Brotherhood of Railway & Airline Clerks which I represent find themselves in an unusual posture in this case.
At the time the second complaint was filed in May 1972 which was the complaint before this Court.
These two lodges had not been in the case for few days short of a year.
They had been eliminated from the case a year before by an order of the District Court which had not been appealed.

Dismissing the 1981 action on the basis, the Tennessee state -- statute of limitations and finding that on the undisputed facts there was no claim, valid claim by the plaintiff against the two union largest and running summary judgments with respect to the Title VII claim.
Consequently, when the second complaint was filed, these two union largest have made a move for dismissal or summary judgment on the basis of res judicata.
The District Court on -- with another judge sitting granted that motion.
We got to the Court of Appeals that was appealed by the petitioner with that issue.

The Court of Appeals focused on the jurisdictional problem in its original opinion and its opinion on rehearing, the petition on rehearing after referring to the jurisdictional problem that specifically stated that the two local unions had a completely -- complete defense against all claims of the petitioner based on res judicata.
The petitioner sought cert in this Court on that issue and this Court denied cert.
Now, the petitioner and their brief, original brief and in their reply brief filed a few days ago says this Court should remand the res judicata issue to the Court of Appeals.
And the amicus brief states that these two local unions are asking this Court to affirm the judgment below in this alternative ground.
Neither one of this are correct in our opinion.
Our position is that that the case when this Court denied certiorari on the issue that ended it.
It is a final and binding judgment now as to these two respondents.
It's the law of the case and moral of the case.
Now, I would like to address myself briefly to the tolling issue.
I'm not going back over the ground that Mr. Wisehart went into.
But I would like to say this.
The petitioner's case boils down simply to this.

They say that in terms of congressional intent and public policy, they must have the tolling principle applied here because of the public policy expressed by Congress in the conciliation process under Title VII.

And petitioner's counsel as I understood it made reference to a plaintiff who had money needed to and who could go ahead with 1981, still needed to file a petition and one who didn't have money needed to wait for conciliation with the EEOC.
Well, of course the one who has the money and wants to go on ahead under 1981 can because all he has to do is wait 180 days and get a right to sue a letter.
This petitioner got a right to sue letter.

He got it about four years later which is the other side of the coin, which is that -- as the amicus brief says, you have to have tolling here to let conciliation work because they say that the EEOC because of its caseload, the lack of money and its budget and lack of staff simply cannot get around the conciliation.
All it means and it meant in this case that you as a matter never have any conciliation at all.

That's the real other side of the coin.So when you finally get around to litigating one of these matters, they have reached the point of being in violation of the principles on which statutes of limitations are based of litigating stale claims which is unfair to the defendants.
Now in there briefs the petitioner says, “No, that's not so here because they say the defendants will have notice from the EEOC that there is a discrimination problem.
So you can't get stale on them.”
Well, the notice that you have after the 1972 Amendment is one little sheet paper with a few boxes on it.
Above all it tells you as there is some discrimination.

Apart of that time you did get a notice with the copy of the complaint but even that didn't give you too much notice because the Sanchez case, and other cases has been cited by petitioner's counsel were so broad in permitting on Title VII complaints.
They had charges different than those before the commission that you didn't really get any notice then either.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So, I take it that a -- the 1981 action is separate and apart from the E -- from the Title VII suit that might eventuate?

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: No, that's an alternative basis for jurisdiction, yes Your Honor.
The facts that are (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I take it that the 1981 action will either be completely distinct or overlapped the Title VII suit.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I have never seen a case that it wasn't just the same facts.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's what I -- what difference does it make it whether the 1981 action survives at all?

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If the Title VII suit maybe broad within time?

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it requires the -- that requires the defendants among other things to be litigating.
Now, these stale issues in a situation --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I understand but (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Yeah, yeah, in this --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Let's assume that the -- that suit is timely brought and it says, there's two counts, one is the Title VII suit and one is the 1981 suit.
Well, the 1981 suit either reach substantive matters or provide remedies that the Title VII suit will not.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: It can reach other matters but usually it does not but it was -- does provide other remedies which can make a substantial --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What's that?
That's what I want to know.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: -- substantial difference to a defendant, complete --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, that's what I want to know.
Why do you feel threatened by the 1981 suit more than a -- separately from this Title VII suit?

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Well, punitive damages is one area, one very major area --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Punitive damages.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Now that you feel threatened in.
The -- there is a statute of limitations now in Title VII that goes back two years from the time the Title VII complaint is filed.
You can -- you could go back further than that in the 1981 if you could go forward with the 1981 --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In some state?

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: In some states, yes.

It might be three or four years in some states so you would have much bigger damages and this becomes a matter of great concern particularly to the unions where you have this big class actions which is what you have.
Now you have hundreds of people you're talking about.
And --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The filing of the EEOC complaint at least puts on notice that there may be eventually a Title VII suit.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: But there's another --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And it also use -- it said that what very frequently involved facts that could give 1981 relief.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: No.
There's another aspect of it Your Honor.
And that is, is that you're lucky if you get a notice from the EEOC.
The cases which we cite in our brief, the EEOC violates the statute, they just don't serve a notice.
And the -- their -- the cases hold that this is not fatal.
I cited the case I'm in now.
I couldn't get the District Court to send it back to the EEOC for conciliation.
We would've loved to conciliate it.
We never heard of the discrimination, alleged discrimination matter until we got served with the complaint.
And the federal court saw that there is no guarantee on the basis of the application of the law, you even -- going to get a notice from the EEOC.
And as I say, the notice you get doesn't show you anything.
It's a -- it's just a single sheet paper with a box on it.
And you would have to be -- you'd have to be a real wizard if you figured out exactly what was involved in it or what the nature of the claim was.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now you represent a union with quite a large membership, I take it.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the union that these two local largest are in is -- that's right, it's a railroad union that has about 200,000 members, these two local largest at that time probably had maybe 75 members.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I don't know that its relevant here, but I wonder if you know any idea how many notices a year, how many complaints a year were filed with EEOC affecting people who were your members or are your members?

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is it a very large number or very small number?

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: It's a very large number.
There is one time, there were pending EEOC and there'd never been conciliation or anything done about them, approximately 200 complaints.
And there's a constant flow of these complaints.
Because of the nature of the individuals that this union represent has a large number of black employees and has large number of women employees it represents.
And it gets substantial number of complaints in both areas.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And I suppose this was something fairly common to any new mechanism of this kind.

turn.speaker: james_l_highsaw_jr
turn.label: Mr. James L. Highsaw, Jr.
turn.text: I think that's right, that's right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Highsaw.
Mrs. Greenberg you have some time left.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: In response to REA's contention that under the regulations, the petitioner's charge might still be pending before the EEOC and therefore this -- there would be tolling forever.
We are only contending that the statute of limitation should be tolled until a notice of right to sue is issued.
Mr. Justice White suggested the possibility of limiting the time for charging, for bringing a suit under 1981 to the time allowed to bring suit under Title VII.
This possibility was suggested in a footnote, in the government's brief citing McAllister versus Magnolia Petroleum.
McAllister is not precedent for limiting the time for bringing a 1981 action to the time for bringing Title VII actions.

We are not asking the court to fashion a time limitation for the bringing of 1981 actions as was done in McAllister but merely to determine the circumstances under which the statute -- the state statute of limitation should be tolled.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And do you think that it should be tolled during the time the compliant is pending and up until the time the right to sue letter is issued.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then the state statute starts running with you.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the time begins when, not with the complaint --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: With the timing --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- with the timing of a charge with the commission, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.
I'm sorry I thought that's --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, isn't that when the tolling begins.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes, that's when the tolling begins.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Tolling period begins under your submission from the Title -- from the time the -- a charged is filed with the commission --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- until the issuance of a right to sue notice by the commission.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Correct?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's your submission.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then it starts running again and it ends whenever the state law would say it ends.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.
In McAllister --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What if that had been here?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: When would it have ended?
I'm sorry I haven't computed that.
I did observe that I think that a hundred and sixty-seven days had passed under that method of computation, a 167 of the one year.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The one year statute.
One year statute.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As construed by this Court.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Tennessee's statute of one year.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

It's not in, just going back to McAllister, again in that case the only way the court could -- the only means that the court could fashion to enable plaintiff to preserve his rights under the unseaworthiness claims was by stretching or extending the time for filing to the time allowed by the Jones Act.
There was no event as in this case which might have triggered the tolling of the state statute of limitations.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mrs. Greenberg, may I ask, you said that about a 167 of the one year period have elapsed --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- when the right to sue -- letter issued, right?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: No.

The -- our contention is that no time had elapsed before the right to sue a letter was issued because the charge which was filed based on continuing violations was filed while plaintiff was still employed by REA.
So that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that -- you mean at the time of the right to sue a letter issued, there was still a year?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Before the 1981 suit to be brought.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.
And was it in fact, what was in the -- in that year?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: The -- yes, the first action was brought less than .30 days, the first Title VII action was --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, when was the 1981 action?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: The 1981 -- the first pleading which included 1981 was the supplemental charge filed by the court-appointed attorney in the first action, 62 days after the recede of the notice of right to sue.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So within the year?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Within -- alright.
Then that was dismissed.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: That was dismissed without prejudiced.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah, but was that the one that said, you have to do something within this -- you have to refile it in a certain time?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: This have -- respondents are in error when they say that the District Court in dismissing the first action provided a time within which a new action have to be filed.
There was no such provision.
I think there are some confusion and there was some confusion in the Court of Appeals.
The --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, the Court of -- did the Court of Appeals think so too?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Well, its not -- its hard to tell but what the decision -- but the ruling was, that is Judge Brown's ruling in the first action was, “If you don't get another lawyer within 30 days, your action will be dismissed without prejudiced.”
It did not say when you could then file a new action.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So -- well, then why was the Title -- the second Title VII suit ever dismissed?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: The second Title VII action was dismissed because the new complaint was not filed within 30 days after the dismissal without prejudice on the grounds that Title VII provided a 30 day statute of limitations for the filing of a Title VII.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, wasn't it because they hadn't -- that they had failed to comply with the court order?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So the rational for dismissing the Title VII suit, second Title VII suit wholly inapplicable to the 1981 action.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the -- then the time for filing it hadn't run and you think it should be sustained.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, you think -- do you think the Title I action should be sustained?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that the --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: I'm sorry --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As timely, as timely.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: I think that the Title VII action should --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, no, the 1981 action.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Oh, the 1981 action was timely, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's why you're here, (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As to the Railway Labor Act point which was first raised by the Chief Justice, we've discussed the Railway Labor Act point at page 18 of our petition for certiorari.
At that place, we cite a number of cases holding that in order to bring a 1981 action, one does not have to exhaust procedural --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm sorry Mrs. Greenberg, I wanted to know, if I get the chronology, a right to sue issue, an initial suit was brought within 30 days which also included the 1981 count, right?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Because --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- was added, it was added.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: It was added.
The problem was that the first -- he couldn't get a lawyer the first time so the judge allowed him to --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) what was dismissed were both actions, when finally the first dismissal, was it?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: The final dismissal because he couldn't get a --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not the final but --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: -- a lawyer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- was an initial dismissal, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: There was an initial interlocutory order dismissing the 1981 actions as not timely filed because of the one year statute not dealing with the tolling issue at all.
And granting summary judgment to the union on their Title VII action and its not clear whether that was on procedural grounds, the motion for summary judgment, it was based on procedural issues.
And granting partial summary judgment on plaintiff's Title VII claims against REA --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) when you got around to filing your second action --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- there was a second action filed, I take it.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You included both 1981 and Title VII?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the -- and that one was dismissed, that one was totally dismissed.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the Title VII was on account of how it didn't comply with the statute of limitations for Title VII.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the 1981 for the same reason as before.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you claim was -- it was wrong just as --

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- exactly erroneous.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

Just to briefly get back to the Railway Labor Act issue and point out that all the cases hold that in every circuit that has considered it, that one does not have to exhaust the EEOC procedural remedies before filing a suit under 1981.
I don't see any reason why one should have to exhaust remedies under the Railway Labor Act.
It has been held by the Eighth Circuit in Norman versus Missouri Pacific that in order to file a Title VII suit, one does not have to exhaust under the Railway Labor Act.
That is the only decision we have found specifically dealing with that other than of course Glover.
I want to address myself further to the REA's argument that one has to apply the -- if one looks to the state statute of limitations, one has to look at all of the state laws.
This was rejected -- was rejected by Mr. Justice Frankfurter in that portion of Holmberg versus Armbrecht that I quoted before.
It is discussed at some length in our reply brief.

And this of course discussed by Justice Friendly, Judge Friendly who said in Moviecolor, for some purposes, you'll look at the state law for some purposes, you look at federal law if you -- if the concerns are federal concerns, you look at federal law.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mrs. Greenberg, are the unions still here in light of our limitation and denial of a certain question, 2c, in your petition?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They still are?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: The Circuit Court when in its footnote, in its opinion denying rehearing which is in the appendix at 115, said that the summary judgment against the unions was res judicata.

Now that summary judgment which is at page 9 -- the order granting summary which is at page 92a, no, I'm sorry, yes, at page 92a of the appendix, paragraph three, goes only to the unions, to the claims against the union under Title VII.
As we --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is there a subsequent judgment entered pursuant to paragraph three of that order granting the motion for summary judgment?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: No.
The only other order in the case was the order dismissing without prejudice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: As to the union as well as to the other defendants.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: As to everyone.
The complaint is dismissed without prejudice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That's kind of inconsistent with the granting of a motion for summary judgment really, isn't it?

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Oh, the granting for motion of -- for summary judgment was an interlocutory order and there never was a final appealable order.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You could -- yeah, that's -- I take it if you could get that in the form of a judgment, you could appeal from that tomorrow.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: If you could get -- I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If you get the District Court to put the granting of summary judgment in the form of a judgment, you could appeal from that tomorrow because there's never been an appealable judgment up to this day.

turn.speaker: deborah_m_greenberg
turn.label: Ms. Deborah M. Greenberg
turn.text: Yes.
That is our position and the question was never certified.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mrs. Greenberg.
Thank you gentlemen.
Case is submitted.
